Posts.Content: On 8/15/2009 butterly13 wrote: I had radiation tx and ended up with severe burns, rash, and horrific 3 1/2x3 1/2" raw skin between under breast and stomach it lays on(DD). I have tried Silver S. and all kinds of contraptions not usinf tape it will tear my skin. Any suggestions? Thanks, Judi M.   I am just beginning my radiation treatment and have not experienced this extreme reaction.  I wonder if you've tried the real aloe plant gel.   Peel back some of the skin from one of the "stalks" and rub the juice directly in, or in this case, sqeeze it on."   Hope it works for you.  IN the mean time, I will pray for complete healing. Posts.Title: Breast Cancer/Radiation Burns and Raw skin treatment

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with stage 2 bc and had a lumpectomy and will be starting 71/2 weeks of radiation next week.  All the margins were clear in the lumpectomy, no cancer in lymph node, PET scan was negative and all blood work is in normal ranges.My cancer was DCIS as well as infiltrating ductal carcinoma and was 2.5 cm large, and graded at a 2.  It had invaded the angiolymphatic vessel and lobeules.  That and size is what put it to stage 2.  I worry about the toxicity of the chemo treatments, am laid off right now needing to get a full time job.  I don't want to damage good cells to and yet was told for every centimeter of cancer there is 1 million cancer cells- yikes!!  My oncologist is willing to let me do the chemo after the radiation if I choose to go forward with it.    I felt at peace with my decision of no chemo til I found out about the 1 million cells of cancer as that gave it a whole new perspective.  The PET scan doesn't pick up things smaller than a cm.    Any thoughts?
Posts.Title: is anyone refusing chemo for breast cancer

Posts.Content: On 8/11/2009 LearnAbout_IPF wrote: Like you I had Stage II DCIS, 5cm,Estogen+, grade 3.  I did lumpectomy and 16 weeks of radiation.  No chemo, my oncologist didn't think it was necessary.  I'm 7 years out, having a few problems with an elevated ca 27.29 but still glad I didn't do chemo.  Thanks for responding.  I wonder if you had any cancer in the sentinal lymph node. 16 weeks is a long time.  Did you go every week Monday to Friday?  Its a tough decision to stand out form the crowd and not follow protocol.  Everyone else is just going forward with traditional surgery, chemo and radiation.   Will look for your reply.  Have a blessed day. LC
